claim: London gets more international arrivals than Paris.

supporting.text: London is a major global financial hub, attracting business travelers from around the world.

attacks.text: London is a major global financial hub, attracting business travelers from around the world.
Paris is also a significant financial center with a strong presence of multinational corporations, which attracts comparable business travel.
Tourism plays a larger role in Paris's international arrivals, and it consistently ranks as the most visited city in the world.
London's financial sector is more globally integrated, with a higher concentration of international banks and financial institutions than Paris.
While Paris is popular for tourism, London's diverse economy ensures a steady inflow of both business and leisure travelers.
The Brexit impact has reduced London's attractiveness as a financial hub, leading to some businesses relocating to Paris.
Paris benefits from its central location in Europe and superior high-speed rail connections, enhancing its appeal for short-term business trips.

supporting.text: London has more international flight connections, with Heathrow being one of the busiest airports globally.

attacks.text: London has more international flight connections, with Heathrow being one of the busiest airports globally.
Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport also ranks among the busiest globally, with comparable international flight connections.
Flight connections alone do not account for other modes of international travel, such as rail or road, where Paris may have an advantage due to its central location in Europe.
Heathrow's passenger traffic significantly exceeds that of Charles de Gaulle, reinforcing London's lead in international arrivals.
London's status as a global financial hub attracts more business travelers, who predominantly use air travel, skewing the data in favor of flight connections.
Passenger traffic does not necessarily correlate with unique international arrivals, as Heathrow may have more connecting flights that do not contribute to London's visitor count.
Business travel has declined post-pandemic, reducing the relevance of London's financial hub status in current arrival statistics.

supporting.text: The UK's historical ties to many countries through the Commonwealth increase travel to London.

attacks.text: The UK's historical ties to many countries through the Commonwealth increase travel to London.
Many Commonwealth countries have weaker economies, limiting their citizens' ability to travel internationally.
Historical ties don't necessarily translate to modern tourism patterns, as new generations may not feel the same connection.
Paris has stronger cultural and linguistic ties to many African and Middle Eastern countries, which may offset London's Commonwealth advantage.
Even with weaker economies, the large populations of Commonwealth countries still generate significant absolute numbers of travelers.
Studies show that diaspora communities maintain strong connections to former colonial powers across generations.
English is a more global language than French, giving London an advantage in attracting international visitors.
The cost of international travel from developing nations means only a small elite can afford trips to London.
While connections exist, they don't necessarily manifest as tourism, with many choosing migration over temporary visits.

supporting.text: Paris is a top tourist destination for cultural attractions like the Louvre and Eiffel Tower, drawing more leisure travelers.

attacks.text: Paris is a top tourist destination for cultural attractions like the Louvre and Eiffel Tower, drawing more leisure travelers.
London has a more diverse economy and attracts more business travelers, increasing its total international arrivals.
London's airports handle significantly more passenger traffic than Paris, indicating higher international arrivals.
London's multicultural environment and global connectivity make it a hub for international visitors beyond just tourism.
Business travel does not necessarily outweigh the sheer volume of leisure tourists drawn to Paris's iconic landmarks.
Airport traffic includes transit passengers who may not be counted as arrivals in London, skewing the comparison.
Paris also has a highly multicultural population and strong global connections, not unique to London.
Leisure tourism is highly seasonal, whereas business travel provides consistent year-round arrivals to London.
Official tourism statistics separate transit passengers from actual arrivals, validating London's higher numbers.

supporting.text: France is the most visited country in the world, with Paris as its primary entry point, suggesting higher arrivals.

attacks.text: France is the most visited country in the world, with Paris as its primary entry point, suggesting higher arrivals.
London has a more diversified economy and global connectivity, attracting more international business travelers than Paris.
London's Heathrow Airport handles more international passengers annually than any airport in Paris, indicating higher arrivals.
Tourism statistics often count domestic visitors, which may inflate Paris's numbers compared to London's primarily international arrivals.
Business travel does not necessarily correlate with total international arrivals, as leisure travelers dominate overall numbers.
Heathrow's passenger volume includes many transit passengers who do not actually visit London, skewing the comparison.
France's domestic tourism is a smaller fraction of total visitors compared to international arrivals in Paris.
Leisure travel trends show London consistently ranking higher in international visitor surveys than Paris.
Even excluding transit passengers, Heathrow's direct arrival numbers surpass those of Parisian airports.

supporting.text: London's higher cost of accommodation and living may deter some international visitors compared to Paris.

attacks.text: London's higher cost of accommodation and living may deter some international visitors compared to Paris.
Despite higher costs, London's diverse cultural attractions and global business hub status attract more visitors.
Many international travelers prioritize experiences over costs, making London's premium pricing less of a deterrent.
London benefits from stronger air connectivity with more direct flights globally, offsetting cost disadvantages.
Paris also has world-class cultural attractions and a strong business sector, narrowing London's advantage.
Budget-conscious travelers may still avoid London due to costs, reducing its overall visitor numbers.
Other European hubs like Frankfurt and Amsterdam compete with London for transit traffic, diluting its connectivity edge.
London's multicultural environment offers unique experiences not replicated in Paris, sustaining its appeal.
The weak pound in recent years has made London relatively more affordable for many international visitors.
